bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, February 16, 1876

div1.p: Reed arranges a visit to Norfolk and Murfreesboro. He describes social events at the army base at Willet's Point.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, February 16, 1876
div1.p:
I am inclined
to agree with my little Sweet-heart
when she says that the day
set aside for correspondence
is the busiest day of all for
her. But may I ask; why does
my little dear allow this to be
so? why does she not do as I
do, and postpone her letter to
some future time, when she will
be less disturbed? Take an in-
stance just at hand- Monday &
Tuesday, I found that it would
be impossible for me to write
to my darling, & hence I post-
poned my letter till to-day- Don't
you see how easy it can
be done? If you should make
the effort, it would surprise
you to see how very easily
it can be done- Of course, when
you said that I would criti-
cise your letter, you were mere-
ly joking, since you can't be ig-
norant of the fact that I never
attempt criticism- I am too well
aware of my own vulnerability
to attempt anything of the kind-
I am the more surprised that
you should be afraid of my
criticisms, since you once told me,
in a letter, that you were “invul-
nerable”- Don't you recall the
remark? I'll refresh your mem-
ory, my darling, when I get to Mur-
freesboro- Now if you should
like to know, at what time I
shall make my appearance,
turn to the last page, at once, &
there you may or you may not
find it- I can't afford to tell
you, this early in my letter, lest
you may lose all interest in
the subsequent narrative -I
am too anxious to hold your
attention at present-

We have had a very gay time,
at the Post, since Saturday last-
On the evening of that day, about
a dozen of us were requested to
appear, in “our best,” at Surgeon
Heger's, to meet a young lady
who had just arrived on that
day- We went- we saw,- but we
did not conquer, to the best of our
knowledge & belief. Of course, we
sat down to a good dinner, &
enjoyed ourselves, during the
the evening, very much- The lady
was young -- light hair, blue eyes,
fair complexion & a tolerably good
smile -- in fact was a blonde-
but nevertheless she was not
pretty- Of course, I know that
I should not say of any lady,
that she is not pretty- I am aware
that I thus acquire the just con-
demnation of all ladies- -but this
is only told to you, my darling, as
my unqualified opinion- Monday
evening, we were again invited over,
to take part in charades, which were
to be the amusement of the evening-
We had a most delightful time,
so much so that we didn't get
“home till morning-” But I must
stop this subject, & tell when I am
coming down to N.C- Should nothing
occur to prevent, I shall spend
a part of Saturday the 26th & Sun-
day the 27th of February in Norfolk,
with Ma. Will come to Murfrees-
boro Monday the 28th & leave the
following Saturday- So that you
need not write, after you receive
this letter-
div1.closer:
Believe me, as ever,
your fond & devoted Walter.
